response:
A subacute optic neuropathy in one eye plus anatomically separate signs of a central sensorimotor lesion in a middle-aged adult strongly suggest an inflammatory demyelinating disease such as multiple sclerosis; neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder and MOG-antibody–associated disease are important alternatives. Structural brain lesions in the left parasagittal region (tumour, meningioma, cavernoma or ACA-territory infarct) can mimic the leg-predominant weakness pattern. Given diabetes and age, non-arteritic anterior ischaemic optic neuropathy is a vascular alternative for the optic nerve involvement, while metabolic myelopathies such as B12 deficiency and coexisting diabetic polyneuropathy could contribute to sensory ataxia.
